repnme.cdata!:
China - Second Irrigated Agriculture
            Intensification Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Second Irrigated
            Agriculture Intensification Project for China was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: The sub-projects were
            small-scale comprehensive agricultural development
            sub-projects, well planned and easily designed. The
            self-financing irrigation and drainage district (SIDDs),
            introduced as a pilot project were successful to a large
            extent. Adequate and Timely Counterpart Funds are Critical.
            Active participation by government leaders at all levels and
            project beneficiaries is very important in ensuring smooth
            project implementation, especially in raising by local
            counterpart funds, organizing contributions of labor for
            large volume earthwork construction, and resolving
            day-to-day project implementation problems and issues. There
            was keen competition among the bidders but there were no
            foreign bidders and, in all cases, the successful bidders
            were local suppliers and manufacturers. The project has
            demonstrated positive economic viability of non-grain
            production to meet changing market and demands when grain
            production was less attractive.

5086940.trustfund:
TF025564-PHRD-IRRIGATED AGRIC.
            INTENSIFICATION PROJ. (BANK-EXEC.),TF035617-CHINA - YANGTZE BASIN WATER
            RESOURCES PROJECT,TF025509-PHRD-SECOND IRRIGATED
            AGRICULTURE INTENSIFICATION PROJ.,TF035870-CHINA - IRRIGATED AGRICULTURE
            INTENSIFICATION II PROJECT
5086940.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Irrigated Agriculture
            Intensification Project aims to 1) increase agricultural
            production; 2) increase farmers  incomes; and 3) establish
            mechanisms for sustainable use, development, and management
            of water and land resources in irrigated areas of the most
            important agricultural production region in China. The
            project covers five provinces with subprojects spread over
            1050 townships in 131 counties in 28 prefectures and cities.
            There are four main components. Component 1 consists of
            irrigation and drainage works, mainly small-scale works,
            including civil works for irrigation and drainage facilities
            improvement and extension, and secondary and tertiary level
            canal rehabilitation. The second finances agricultural
            intensification and support services, including land and
            soil improvement; provision for more intensive use of
            organic fertilizer; strengthening production of high quality
            seeds; improving agricultural extension systems with better
            facilities, equipment, and staff training; establishing
            fertilizer blending plants to provide chemical fertilizer;
            building organic manure digesting pits; providing
            agricultural production inputs and materials; and promoting
            science & technology and integrated pest management.
            Component 3, afforestation and environmental monitoring,
            increases the vegetative cover as well as controls pests and
            disease, and provides machinery and equipment. Component 4
            supports project implementation and management, and
            institutional development.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Second Irrigated Agriculture
            Intensification Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The study introduces the policy
            framework of the social assessment on land acquisition, and
            resettlement issues due to the project's impact.
            Involuntary resettlement, and selection of irrigation
            subprojects, were taken into consideration in project
            design, in accordance with Bank guidelines, and Chinese
            laws, and regulations. To minimize adverse effects on
            farmers, caused by the project's land occupation,
            construction, and housing relocation, recommendations
            include quality upgrade of specified standards, by dredging,
            and repairing existing branch canals, laterals, and ditches
            as possible. Additionally, in some arable lands, the length
            of ditches could be reduced, by replacing the curved on-farm
            ditches with straight ones, and, if construction of new ones
            is required, the farm land area of each household will be
            adjusted during land leveling to ensure no area losses, and
            ensure as well, that works be adjusted to the planting
            season, to avoid any waste of crops. To maximize land uses,
            canal profiles will be designed to control infiltration, and
            reduce the canal cross-section areas. The study indicates
            that the departments of land management have guaranteed
            compensation, based on replacement costs, for those people
            whose livelihoods may be affected by land acquisition, and,
            provide as well, work benefits, and, grievance mechanisms,
            to ensure their living standards, and rights are not disrupted.
